questions.question: Question 1: Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following medical conditions except:
questions.explanation:
227 
Sold by @itachibot Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following conditions except hypothyroidism. 
Hyperthyroidism is however associated with hypercalcemia. Other options: 1) Multiple myeloma is a hemotological malignancy associated with hypercalcemia. 2) Hyperparathyroidism is associated with sub-periosteal bone resorption resulting in 
hypercalcemia. 3) Sarcoidosis is associated with hypercalcemia due to increased activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase 
activity in the macrophages.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following can cause hypercalcemia in a patient?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A intoxication can cause hypercalcemia. This is due to high bone turnover. Ingestion of 
50,000–100,000 units of Vitamin A daily can increase calcium levels up to 12–14 mg/dL. Note: Vitamin D intoxication also leads to hypercalcemia.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 3: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious 
by her neighbors. She is found to have marked dehydration and serum calcium levels of 16 
mg/dl. All of the following can cause this presentation except:
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario with severe hypercalcemia (> 14.8 mg/dl) is suggestive of a hypercalcemic 
crisis. Pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemic crisis is often caused by malignancies due to an acute rise in calcium levels 
following bone resorption due to metastases. It is a medical emergency that presents with 
polyuria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to 
cardiac arrest and coma.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not seen in patients following excessive intake of calcium?
questions.explanation:
Excess calcium ingestion is not associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy. It results in milk-alkali 
syndrome, commonly associated with excessive intake of absorbable antacids such as milk or 
calcium carbonate. In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium 
absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features: • Hypercalcemia • Alkalosis - due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water 
depletion. • Renal failure - due to damage to renal tubules. It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form 
called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Parathyroid adenomas are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism: • Parathyroid adenomas: These maybe 229 
Sold by @itachibot • Solitary (more common) • Multiple • Part of MEN-1, MEN-2A or MEN-4 • Chief cell parathyroid hyperplasia • Parathyroid gland carcinoma • Lithium use • Hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor (HPT-™T) syndrome
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following sets of lab values will be seen in a patient with secondary 
hyperparathyroidism? 220 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Secondary hyperparathyroidism presents with decreased calcium and increased levels of PTH, 
phosphate, and ALP. In this condition, calcium deficiency leads to reactive stimulation of the parathyroid. It is caused 
by the following: • Chronic kidney disease • Vitamin D deficiency • Gastrointestinal malabsorption • Liver disease
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 8: All of the following statements are true about primary hyperparathyroidism except:

options.a: It causes prolongation of QT interval

questions.explanation:
Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) causes shortening of the QT interval. The asymptomatic form is the most common presentation in the Western population. But in 
developing countries, the patients are usually symptomatic. The classical symptoms and signs of 
PHPT are due to hypercalcemia as well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows: The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows: • Osteitis fibrosa cystica • Osteopenia/osteoporosis • Hyperuricemia and gout • Pseudogout • Increased production of calcitriol • Nephrolithiasis • Hypophosphatemia • Anemia 230

questions.question: Question 10: Calcitonin levels are increased in:
questions.explanation:
Calcitonin levels are increased in hyperparathyroidism. Due to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in hyperparathyroidism, there is osteoclast 
activation. This leads to increased calcium levels in plasma. As a response to this, there is an 
increase in the level of calcitonin to regulate the high calcium levels. Calcitonin is secreted by the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its principal effects are to 
lower serum calcium and phosphate by its action on bone and kidney. In bone, calcitonin inhibits 
osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. In the kidney, it inhibits the reabsorption of both 
calcium and phosphate. Other options Option A: In hyperthyroidism, the direct effect of thyroid hormones can lead to bone resorption 
and mild hypercalcemia. However, hyperparathyroidism is a better answer. Options B and D: Hypoparathyroidism and Cushing’s syndrome will have low serum calcium and 
hence, will not have increased calcitonin levels.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 11: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It 
is associated with elevated ALP. It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics 
the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides 
of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae. Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of 
vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey 232 
Sold by @itachibot spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there 
is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance. Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral 
bodies.

questions.question:
Question 12: A middle-aged woman presents with worsening pain and an inability to bear weight on her 
left leg. She says that she had banged her leg against a chair 3 days ago. X-ray reveals a 
fracture of her left tibia. In view of this finding, a skeletal survey was performed and reveals 
the following additional finding. What is the likely cause? 222 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pathological fracture of the tibia. The given x-ray shows 
brown tumors or osteitis fibrosa cystica, which are characteristic of hyperparathyroidism.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 13: This x-ray finding in a patient is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The arrows in this x-ray point to arrow-headed fingers or the spade phalanx sign. It is 
pathognomonic of acromegaly. Acromegaly is the result of excessive growth hormone (GH) production, most commonly from a 
macroadenoma of the pituitary. There is osseous enlargement, presenting with spade-like hands 
and widening of the terminal phalangeal tufts, giving an arrow-head appearance. Other features in the hand include: • Widened joint spaces (due to cartilage hypertrophy) • Generalized osteoporosis and cystic changes in the carpal bones Option A: Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, which is marked along the 
radial aspect of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. Option B: Down's syndrome can cause hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger. Option C: Psoriasis causes a pencil-in-cup appearance of the distal phalanx.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following is not used to treat a patient with hypercalcemia due to primary 
hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids have no effect on the serum calcium concentration in primary 
hyperparathyroidism and normal individuals. They are effective in the treatment of hypercalcemia when associated with the following 
conditions: • Malignancy • Vitamin D intoxication • Sarcoidosis Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following: • Normal saline (200-500 ml/hour): It is the mainstay treatment to correct dehydration, and 
titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour 233 
Sold by @itachibot • Pamidronate or zoledronate: These are bisphosphonates and are considered as the drug of 
choice in primary hyperparathyroidism • Cinacalcet: This is a calcimimetic that increases the affinity of the glands to extracellular 
calcium, thereby decreasing parathyroid hormone secretion • Denosumab: This inhibits RANK-ligand, which acts on osteoclasts • Calcitonin: This is an activated vitamin D analog that may be used to reduce calcium levels. It 
should be used within the first 24 hours Forced diuresis refers to aggressive fluid hydration with loop diuretic administration. Although 
this is an effective method to reduce calcium levels, it requires careful monitoring for adverse 
effects like fluid overload, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesia. Due to this reason as well as the 
availability of more effective treatment modalities, forced diuresis is not preferred any longer. The definitive management of primary hyperparathyroidism is the surgical removal of the 
parathyroid gland.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity?
questions.explanation:
In patients with hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity, glucocorticoids like dexamethasone are 
the preferred therapy as they decrease 1,25 (OH2) vitamin D (calcitriol) production. This results in 
reduced intestinal calcium absorption and increased urinary excretion of calcium. Hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, and ketoconazole may also decrease calcitriol production and 
are used occasionally. But the preferred therapy is steroids. Vitamin D toxicity presents acutely with features of hypercalcemia such as confusion, polyuria, 
polydipsia, anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Chronic intoxication may cause 
nephrocalcinosis, bone demineralization, and pain. Lab features include elevated 25 (OH) vitamin D, high calcium, and suppressed PTH. Dexamethasone can also be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by the humoral 
hypercalcemia of malignancy (due to PTHr) and sarcoidosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient is brought to the emergency department with confusion, drowsiness, and multiple 
episodes of vomiting. His family members say that he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder 
several years ago and has been on medication ever since. Further evaluation reveals a serum 
calcium level of 16 mg/dl. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. The next best step in management is 
saline hydration. Typically 200-500 ml/hour fluids are given to correct dehydration and titrated to 
maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour. Hypercalcemic crisis is a medical emergency associated with serum calcium >14 mg/dl. It is 
often caused by conditions causing an acute rise in calcium levels such as malignancies or lithium 
overdose. It presents with oliguria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered 
consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma. Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following: 234 
Sold by @itachibot • Fluids are the mainstay treatment • Bisphosphonates • Cinacalcet • Denosumab • Calcitonin
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 19: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his mother with with the following abnormality. Serum levels 
of vitamin D are found to be low. Which of the following would not be seen in this boy?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a windswept deformity of the lower limbs (combination of valgus 
deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg). This finding along with low serum 
vitamin D points to a diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency rickets. It is associated with an increase 
in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to hypocalcemia?
questions.explanation:
Hypocalcemia is a feature of secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT). Hypocalcemia refers to total serum calcium 8.4 mg/dl. The causes include: • Low PTH • Hypoparathyroidism • High PTH (SHPT) • Chronic kidney disease • Vitamin D deficiency • Pseudohypoparathyroidism 236 
Sold by @itachibot • Hyperphosphatemia • Loop diuretics, calcitonin, bisphosphonates • Massive blood transfusions • Hyperventilation • Hypomagnesemia - Mg is essential for PTH release • Severe hypermagnesemia - higher Mg levels suppress PTH secretion Hypocalcemia causes tetany or increased neuromuscular excitability. It can cause paresthesias, 
cramps, spasms, and seizures. Latent tetany can only be detected by performing Chvostek and 
Trousseau's signs. A prolonged QT interval is seen on ECG.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question: Question 21: The following sign is elicited in a patient. What is it called?
questions.explanation:
The above image indicates Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm classically seen in patients 
with hypocalcemia. Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer 
cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The 
hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. Hypocalcemia results in tetany or increased neuromuscular irritability. It leads to paresthesia and 
tingling of extremities and perioral area. Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures. Option A: Chvostek's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. Tapping the facial nerve in front of the 
tragus will cause spasms of the facial muscles. Option C: Tinel's sign is seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It refers to a tingling sensation on 
tapping over the median nerve. Option D: Troisier's sign refers to left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal 
malignancy.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following agents cannot be used to manage a patient with chronic 
hypocalcemia? 226 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Etidronate is not used in the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate used in the 
management of hypercalcemia. The goal in the management of hypoparathyroidism is to restore the calcium-phosphate balance. 
The mainstay is calcium and vitamin D supplements. Other underlying conditions must also be 
treated. Instead of loop diuretics, thiazides can be administered on a low sodium diet as they enhance 
urinary calcium reabsorption. 237 
Sold by @itachibot Obesity
